verses.text: Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior, but he was the son of a prostitute. Gilead was Jephthah’s father.
verses.comment: Maintains the phrasing referring to Jephthah's mother's status; other translations euphemize this.

verses.text: Gilead’s wife also bore him sons, and when his wife’s sons grew up, they drove Jephthah away and said to him, 'You shall not inherit in our father’s house, for you are the son of another woman.'
verses.comment: Preserves the original reason for Jephthah's rejection by his half-brothers.

verses.text: Then Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob. Worthless men gathered around Jephthah and went out with him.
verses.comment: Keeps the word 'worthless' as used in most literal translations for the type of people that joined Jephthah.

verses.text: After some time, the Ammonites fought against Israel.
verses.comment: Simple, direct rendering of the event's timing and context.

verses.text: And when the Ammonites made war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah from the land of Tob.
verses.comment: Direct translation of the elders' action.

verses.text: They said to Jephthah, 'Come and be our leader, so that we may fight against the Ammonites.'
verses.comment: Retains the sense of their request—'leader' not 'ruler' or 'commander.'

verses.text: But Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, 'Did you not hate me and drive me out of my father’s house? Why have you come to me now when you are in trouble?'
verses.comment: Jephthah’s reply preserves the original question and tone.

verses.text: The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, 'This is why we have turned to you now, so that you may go with us and fight against the Ammonites and be head over all the inhabitants of Gilead.'
verses.comment: The shift from 'leader' to 'head' in this verse follows the original text.

verses.text: Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, 'If you bring me home again to fight against the Ammonites, and the LORD gives them to me, then shall I be your head?'
verses.comment: 'Head' remains as in the original Hebrew, denoting leadership over Gilead.

verses.text: The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, 'The LORD will be witness between us, if we do not do as you say.'
verses.comment: Retains the original covenant language ('The LORD will be witness').

verses.text: So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and leader over them. And Jephthah spoke all his words before the LORD at Mizpah.
verses.comment: Retains both titles 'head and leader'—matching Hebrew terms.

verses.text: Then Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites and said, 'What do you have against me, that you have come me to fight against my land?'
verses.comment: A direct question reflecting the original—Jephthah makes his inquiry personal and territorial.

verses.text: The king of the Ammonites answered the messengers of Jephthah, 'Because Israel, when they came up from Egypt, took away my land from the Arnon as far as the Jabbok, and all the way to the Jordan. Now therefore restore those lands peacefully.'
verses.comment: Translation maintains the geographical details as quoted by the king.

verses.text: Jephthah sent messengers again to the king of the Ammonites,
verses.comment: Simple rendering matching Hebrew syntax.

verses.text: and said to him, 'Thus says Jephthah: Israel did not take away the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites.'
verses.comment: Direct speech, 'Thus says Jephthah,' as in original dialogues.

verses.text: 'For when they came up from Egypt, Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea and came to Kadesh.'
verses.comment: Maintains sequence and travel locations.

verses.text: 'Israel then sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, "Please let us pass through your land." But the king of Edom would not listen. So they sent also to the king of Moab, but he would not consent. So Israel remained at Kadesh.'
verses.comment: Quotes the requests and refusals as in original; adds quotes for clarity.

verses.text: 'Then they went through the wilderness and circled the land of Edom and the land of Moab, and came to the east side of the land of Moab, and camped beyond the Arnon. But they did not enter the territory of Moab, for the Arnon was the border of Moab.'
verses.comment: Preserves geographical detail.

verses.text: 'Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, the king of Heshbon, and Israel said to him, "Please let us pass through your land to our place."'
verses.comment: Retains specific names and diplomatic request.

verses.text: 'But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory. So Sihon gathered all his people and encamped at Jahaz and fought with Israel.'
verses.comment: Direct translation of denial and subsequent battle.

verses.text: 'And the LORD, the God of Israel, gave Sihon and all his people into the hand of Israel, and they defeated them. So Israel took possession of all the land of the Amorites, who lived in that region.'
verses.comment: Unifies victorious events under God’s action.

verses.text: 'They took possession of all the territory of the Amorites, from the Arnon to the Jabbok, and from the wilderness to the Jordan.'
verses.comment: Faithful geographical summary.

verses.text: 'So now, the LORD, the God of Israel, has driven out the Amorites before his people Israel, and should you possess it?'
verses.comment: Preserves rhetorical force of Jephthah’s argument.

verses.text: 'Will you not possess what Chemosh your god gives you to possess? So we will possess what the LORD our God has given us.'
verses.comment: Chemosh referenced as Ammonite deity per original text; no euphemisms or edits.

verses.text: 'Now are you any better than Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever contend with Israel, or did he ever fight against them?'
verses.comment: Preserves rhetorical question for effect.

verses.text: 'While Israel lived in Heshbon and its villages, and in Aroer and its villages, and in all the cities that are along the Arnon, for three hundred years, why did you not recover them within that time?'
verses.comment: Keeps the historical argument and mention of 'three hundred years.'

verses.text: 'Therefore I have not sinned against you, but you do me wrong by making war on me. The LORD, the Judge, decide this day between the people of Israel and the people of Ammon.'
verses.comment: Direct, judicial language as in original; keeps 'The LORD, the Judge.'

verses.text: But the king of the Ammonites did not listen to the words of Jephthah that he sent to him.
verses.comment: Plain rendering as per Hebrew.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah, and he passed through Gilead and Manasseh and passed on to Mizpah of Gilead, and from Mizpah of Gilead he advanced toward the Ammonites.
verses.comment: Includes 'Spirit of the LORD' as empowerment and matches the movement sequence.

verses.text: Jephthah made a vow to the LORD, saying, 'If you will indeed give the Ammonites into my hand,'
verses.comment: Direct vow, conditionally phrased as in the original.

verses.text: 'then whatever comes out from the doors of my house to meet me when I return in peace from the Ammonites shall be the LORD’s, and I will offer it up for a burnt offering.'
verses.comment: Faithful to Hebrew ambiguity; some translations clarify 'whoever', but here retains the ambiguity ('whatever').

verses.text: So Jephthah crossed over to the Ammonites to fight against them, and the LORD gave them into his hand.
verses.comment: Direct battle narrative, maintains God's action.

verses.text: And he struck them from Aroer to the neighborhood of Minnith—twenty cities—and as far as Abel-keramim, with a very great slaughter. So the Ammonites were subdued before the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Geographic extent and details kept.

verses.text: Then Jephthah came to his home at Mizpah. And behold, his daughter came out to meet him with tambourines and with dancing. She was his only child; besides her he had neither son nor daughter.
verses.comment: Preserves emotional tone and uniqueness of Jephthah’s daughter.

verses.text: And when he saw her, he tore his clothes and said, 'Alas, my daughter! You have brought me very low, and you have become a cause of great distress to me. For I have opened my mouth to the LORD, and I cannot take back my vow.'
verses.comment: Keeps original expressions of grief and about the irrevocability of vows.

verses.text: She said to him, 'My father, you have opened your mouth to the LORD; do to me according to what has gone out of your mouth, since the LORD has avenged you on your enemies, on the Ammonites.'
verses.comment: Retains submission and theological reasoning as in Hebrew.

verses.text: She said to her father, 'Let this thing be done for me: Let me be alone for two months, that I may go up and down on the mountains and weep for my virginity, I and my companions.'
verses.comment: 'Virginity' retained as in original; describes the mourning with friends.

verses.text: He said, 'Go.' So he sent her away for two months, and she left, she and her companions, and wept for her virginity on the mountains.
verses.comment: 'Go' is literal, and 'wept for her virginity' matches the original tone.

verses.text: At the end of two months, she returned to her father, who did to her according to his vow that he had made. She had never known a man. And it became a custom in Israel
verses.comment: Careful to report Jephthah's fulfillment and the note of her perpetual virginity, without any embellishment.

verses.text: that the daughters of Israel went year by year to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in the year.
verses.comment: Maintains 'lament,' as in more literal translations, not 'commemorate.'
